# Rivest Shamir forgot Adleman

## Solution

From the source code, we can see that the flag encrypted into ```ct```. The ```n``` value is much bigger than ```e``` and ```ct```, so we can ignore it in the solve script. 
```python
from Crypto.Util.number import *

p = getPrime(1024)
q = getPrime(1024)

n = p*q
e = 123589168751396275896312856328164328381265978316578963271231567137825613822284638216416
m = bytes_to_long(b"nbctf{[REDACTED]}")

ct = (m^e) % n

print("n = ", n)
print("e = ", e)
print("ct = ", ct)
```
Output
```
n =  
e =  123589168751396275896312856328164328381265978316578963271231567137825613822284638216416
ct =  159269674251793083518243077048685663852794473778188330996147339166703385101217832722333
```
<br>

Since XOR operation is reversible, we can change the position of ```ct``` and ```m``` to get the flag. Converts ```m``` to ```long_to_bytes``` then we get the flag.

```python
from Crypto.Util.number import *

n = 
e = 123589168751396275896312856328164328381265978316578963271231567137825613822284638216416
ct = 159269674251793083518243077048685663852794473778188330996147339166703385101217832722333

m = (ct^e) 

print("m = ", long_to_bytes(m).decode())
```

## Flag
The flag for this challenge is ```nbctf{wh0_t0ld_m3_t0_u53_xors!?!?!?}```.
